instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I have a small pile of <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards that all have the same issue; they have quarter-fan spin (twitch), and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is at ~.6-.8v. They all had no liquid, no apparent damage, and I was wondering if anyone has resolved this type of issue before on this specific board? I've spent hours trying to determine what is causing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> to be low, but can't figure it out. I've had help in previous threads recommending I remove <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>-67 one-by-one and see which of those rails is pulling down <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, but on each board, I removed those resistors and the signal stayed low each time. I got stuck on all of them, and set them aside. I am 100% confident they have no liquid damage. I'm positive they haven't been worked on before. PP3v42, ppbus, ppvrtc, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, 5v/3v sus, etc., all present. Boards do not power on with battery or charger. Checked BIOS chips, swapped from good board to see if it improved things, and nothing.

Is there anything else I need to check? Has anyone else had this issue and resolved it successfully? I've already checked the obvious culprits--<CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, shorts on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, etc., and nothing changes it. ISL area is all good, of course, and my main rails are all present. Are these likely dead PCH/CPUs? Could it be a bad SMC? I really want to figure these boards out, and they all have the exact same symptoms.

Any leads appreciated. I can provide specific measurements if needed, but I'm really asking more of a specific question as to whether or not anyone has solved a similar issue. I'm out of ideas of where to look, and I hate to use boards that should be repairable for parts boards.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I just ran a wire from pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> to pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> (to get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> to show up), and the board powers on. I only left it on for a second, for fear this could do some sort of damage. 

Not having a real good understanding of how this circuit works, would this help indicate the failure? I assume one of my 5 pwrgd feeder signals are missing (<SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is present), but I can't seem to find one that is...? Just wanted to include this information, as it may be helpful.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Did the board post? 

Ive had something odd like this before on a 2936. See if you get a steady fan by removing the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistor on one of them. Its an odd way of troubleshooting but if the fan stays on then you can take measurements with allot less faffing about.
Thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: With a wire at <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>, the board powers on but gives the no-ram three beep. Which resistor are you referring to on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7860</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R7862</RESISTOR>. Essentially the plan is to brick an S0 rail to find out if it still pulses or actually remains on.

Ive had similar symtoms to what your getting caused by <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> going bad before. No liquid.ect 

I find the fastest way to diagnose these strange issues is by breaking power rails one by one until you maybe get a fan spin. Work from the top backwards, By removing <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> you also remove <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, Which means you also remove <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> voltages.

A board missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> will still spin up and stay on with missing power rails, I think whats happening is that something occurs after <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is causing it to turn back off.

-Im going to look like an idiot if this doesn't get you anywhere ahaha.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: You have to distinguish an <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> issue and a power cycling issue. If CPU Vcore is also pulsing then <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is fine. If CPU Vcore is not pulsing then <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is probably not coming all the way high. Best to check this with a scope.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Thanks, Duke! I do get a pulse on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> every ~4-5 seconds, so I believe you're right, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is fine. What would you recommend to check next? A short on the lower rails?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Jumper <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> again so that it stays on and measure all the rails that are involved in generating it. Then see if they are all actually present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thanks, Duke--will do!

I wanted to add a bit of information to an above post: when I ran the jumper to force <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>, I got the 3-beep no-RAM indication, even with RAM installed in the board. I realize I didn't specifically state that I had RAM installed in that post.

Will update thread tomorrow--thanks!

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
OK, I have some more information on this one.

I re-ran the jumper, and found that <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> is missing (.371v). This rail missing also means that <SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing, which explains my three-beeps when the board powers on.

I traced <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> back to <CHIP>U7801</CHIP> and found these measurements:   pin1) 5v   2) .20v   3) .20v   4) 0v   5) 1.5v   6) .371v   7) .012v   8) .08v

I then checked <TRANSISTOR>Q3205</TRANSISTOR>, and got these measurements:   pin1) 0v   2) 0v   3) 0v   4) 0v   5) 3.3v   6) .20v

Compared to a working board, it looks like I should have 1.05v on pin 6 (<SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL>) of <TRANSISTOR>Q3205</TRANSISTOR>...which I believe explains my issue. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is present at <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>.

I hope my CPU isn't dead. :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is present on both pins of <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>?? If yes check continuity between pin 2 from <CHIP>U7801</CHIP> to pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Hey Aprendiz--thanks! I checked <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>, and pin 1 I have 3.3v and pin 2 is .20v. <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR> measures out fine (9.72k).

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
[SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Thanks, Aprendiz! I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3205</TRANSISTOR>, and unfortunately there was no change. Still have .20v at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>. :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: The last thing that can pull down <SIGNAL>P1V5CPU_EN</SIGNAL> is <CHIP>U7801</CHIP>........ Measure resistance to ground on pin 2 from <CHIP>U7801</CHIP>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]Question about low <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thanks, Aprendiz--you're the man.

RTG on pin 2 of <CHIP>U7801</CHIP> was 390ohms, diode mode showed .143. This is a lot different than a good board, so I replaced <CHIP>U7801</CHIP> and all seems well. Thank goodness the CPU wasn't at fault.

This one can be marked as solved! Thanks again, guys!
